comments.value:
- we need to figure out some way of letting ppl pick only the 23rd, 24th, or 25th, if they select open weekend (maybe tick boxes)

Please see previous conversation on this ticket here, but reply via this ticket
http://postcms.zendesk.com/tickets/797

1) we need to figure out some way of letting ppl pick only the 23rd, 24th, or 25th, if they select open weekend (maybe tick boxes)

We don't actually have that information on the event or the submission form in any structured format (we have start /end date)
http://www.london2012.com/get-involved/open-weekend/information-for-event-organisers/submit-an-event/index.php

We could in theory add three new check boxes for Open weekend Sat [x] | Sun [ ] | Mon [x] (although someone would need to go back and fill them in by hand) but these would be flags and not dates (in terms of search by dates).

This means we could use them to visually flag up particular events as Sat/Sun/Mon/All and in addition we could add two new check boxes under the normal search options (Saturday only [ ] Sunday only [ ]) when Open weekend is selected that limited events to just that day, we'd also need to get these to remember the submitted values and auto check those boxes when the page is submitted.

None of the above is trivial and without issue:

a) all events will end up with these three new check boxes, given the amount of OW fields already on the Events page maybe two more isn't going to break the camels back
b) someone will need to fix up all the existing events
c) we'll need to update the OW submission form, the code that handles form submissions and the event page itself.
d) we'll need to add new check boxes (and sort out the css/layout) for them to the search form and make sure they only appear when OpenWeeknd option is selected); we'll also need to make these boxes auto check when a search is performed.
e) we'll need to change the search engine to take account of the three new boxes and then limit the results to Open Weekend events with with the Sat or Sun checkboxes.
f) this field won't actually affect any date searches (as it's not a date field it's just a flag; probably not an immediate issue, just means that events will stil have to be given a start/end date as they currently are)
f) develop on dev, test, deploy to live and test some more

All in all at least a days work.

Jamie
Set to high. Still pending.

I'm a bit confused on this.  Might be worth talking about.  We would never have an event on just the sat and then the monday.  either it's inclusive (so fri-sun or fri-sat) or just one day.  How is what we've got with start/end date terribly different to that?

Did our conversation the other day help clear this up at all?

Hi Liz,

OK that makes it simpler as (as you say) we already have the start / 
end date, so the data model and the submit for statys the same.

We just need to add some check boxes to the search form (as we're 
sharing the same search for normal events, I assume you only want them 
to show when OW is selected as the event date)

We then need to add some new logic to the back end to filter the 
searches by those check boxes (and maybe pre check them in the results)

Jamie

Hi Jamie,

, I assume you only want them
to show when OW is selected as the event date) --> yes, please

And yes, again.

Could you quote? I’d like them to pay for it.

1 day to make changes, test and deploy.

I know I originally said one day for the more complex route, but we are finding that even though the development work on events may only take 3/4 of a day we are spending at least another 1/4 of a day on handover, questions, post launch questions, clarifications etc. [ie. non dev stuff] and need to recoup some of that time, especially as currently the time we have spent on events far outweighs what we have billed you so far, I hope you understand.

thanks 

Jamie
Fine! I’ll let them know, and see if they really want it. ☺
I still need to chase OW team on this... I'm working on it!
Right!  They would like this, please.  Separate PO for £700

dev does it:
http://london2012dev.kitsite.com/get-involved/upcoming-events/index.php

Changes:
- there's an 'Open weekend' event date option
- when it's selected, little checkboxes appear (saying Fri, Sat, Sun)
- It will show events that fit to the dates checked in the checkboxes

As open weekend events are not published on live, I guess this will sit on dev until the publication happens - is there an eta for that?

Hi Liz,

This will allow you to show up to date related pages / links without the need to republish all pages.

So a generic content page will show the latest *related* events that are tagged to that pages tags.

Jamie

That is what i thought. It's also very exciting. When will we know if it's possible? And what is the actually reason that it Might be possible?

I have reset the due date, as one week from today. I will liaise with Janos, and report back.
Commentary: the event regions have now been harmonized. Will report on the rest of the related events changes next week.

Am marking this ticket as closed.
The new functionality is as follows:
On all pages that display "related events", a search is made for: "All upcoming events which match one or more of this page's metadata". If any are found then we display a "Related events" heading, and up to 4 related events, ordered by date.
If none is found then we simply display an old-style "Upcoming events" heading, followed by up to 4 /upcoming/ events, irrespective of location or theme, ordered by date.
For example, if you visit the following page

http://www.london2012.com/news/2010/03/more-than-10-000-businesses-engaged-on-london-2012-opportunities.php

You'll see that it displays three =related= events:

1. http://www.london2012.com/events/london-business-network-event-stratford.php
2. http://www.london2012.com/events/international-youth-theatre-festival.php
3. http://www.london2012.com/events/london-business-network-event-central-london.php

These were found because they are tagged to theme:Business (1) & (3) or to region:East Midlands (2).

If, however, you visit the following page:

http://www.london2012.com/news/2010/05/london-2012-mascots-launched-to-the-world.php

You'll see that it simply displays 4 =upcoming= events. i.e. the next 4 events anywhere/tagged to anything. This is because this news article has no metadata. It just has a freetext:mascot tag.

I hope the above makes sense. If you have any questions, please ask.

As noted below, extending this functionality to news and photos should be possible, but should form a separate task.

Kieran
Danny, although actual days = 2, I think we should bill for one day, and then recoup the lost time if/when they request similar functionality for news/photos.

Kieran.

I didn’t know it was live! So if I go in and add keywords to events, they’ll start to appear in related areas? Or is it only meta-themes it’s searching for? It still looks like all events are appearing on all pages? These events are clearly not related to funding...

[cid:image001.png@01CB0D3F.EFE516A0]

  http://www.london2012.com/making-it-happen/funding-the-games/index.php
is not tagged with any metadata. Therefore the links that appear on the RHS are simply "Upcoming events", rather than "/Related/ events".
If you tag this page to a theme or a region, then it should start displaying /Related/ events.

(If you scroll back to my earlier comment, I tried to explain this in detail - obviously let me know if this is still unclear).

Sorry, Kieran – I didn’t see the zendesk update email and thus hadn’t realised you’d updated the ticket! That’s very clear. I’m wondering, though, if it would actually be better to *remove* upcoming events altogether. So if a page has no related events, display nothing, rather than updated ones. Is that easy to do? I just that users won’t notice the subtle difference in wording.

Can you please just clarify – is this only looking for the metadata themes (e.g. Culture, Sustainability, Basketball) or *all* keywords in the metadata (e.g. Seb Coe, athletes, etc) ?

Depending on the above, I think this is probably ideal for related news/blogs/photos/vids.

1. "Upcoming events". We could of course suppress this. Might it not look a bit empty if we did this though? Another option might be to /always/ display upcoming events, and then - if there are any - also display "related" events. Suppressing "Upcoming events" would be relatively simple - adding about 1/4 day to the actual days.

2. Currently it just searches on metadata. i.e. NOT on the freetext tags. This is - again - something we can change. it does involve a mass republication though. I estimate another 1/2 day to get this working.

3. news/blogs/photos/vids. What do you mean by "news" and "blogs" ?

4. Changing the "related photos" / "related videos" components to use this functionality would be 3/4 day each. I know I said 1/2 day each, below, but I have since realised that I will have to perform a mass republication, and also that they're not just simple text links like the related events.

I hope this makes sense.

Kieran

1) We’ve gotten feedback that just having random upcoming, unrelated events on lots of pages is more distracting than helpful. So suppressing would be a good thing

2) It would be really good if we can have it work on freetext tags – Jamie’s original concern was that it would significantly slow down load time – is that no longer the case?

3) At the bottom of all pages we have related news and blogs. These work just like pictures and video at the moment – only related news/blogs appear, but you have to republish the page in order for it to take effect. My understanding of what you’ve done for events is that we would no longer have to republish an individual page in order for the most recent related content (right now just events) to be picked up

4) Unclear how the type of content would affect things, but otherwise understood.

1. Ok. This will go live when I deploy 2,3,4.

I'm leaving 1. on this ticket.
For 2,3,4 I'm creating a new ticket.

comments.value:
Afternoon you guys.

Visit Britain want to take an RSS feed of all Open Weekend events so they can display them on their website.  Can you advise if / how this is acheivable?  I'm not sure if you and Liz have discussed this yet or not as i'm told this has been a pending request from VB for a little while, but any info would be great so I can send it back to VB.

I should clarify, they’re not asking us to convert the events into any cleaner looking format for them to display, they literally just want the RSS so they can write something to display it nicely on their site themselves.

Hi Finn,

No we don't and haven't' seen any tickets in ZenDesk referring to creating one.

In terms of creating one, the first question is do you really mean a RSS feed (*) or is that just being used as a catch all term for an basic XML feed of all events in a structured format delivered via the web, that Visit Britain can load in and use on their site.

* RSS feeds tend to just contain 15 items each one of which just contains a title, link and a short description, creator and date can be added as option elements picked up by some RSS readers.

Obviously a simple RSS feed of 15 upcoming events is simpler to get setup than a full blown feed, there is also a question (if we go down the RSS route) around how often the RSS feed will be retrieved. Will Visit Britain pull it every time a page loads on their site or will they retrieve it once a day and cache it. I don't really care ;-) but I know ITS are sensitive about this sort of thing esp. as each request will be a hit on our search index as the results returned will have to be upcoming events.

Jamie

Jamie, lots of useful info, ta. Based on your description I reckon it’s the XML they’d want. From your side of things, how much work do you reckon it’d involve?

Jag – Please see below. Would it be an issue for you guys if Visit Britain were to retrieve an XML feed of all the events on london2012.com once a day (for a time around Open Weekend) and cached it? They want to host our events on their site too and they were hoping to develop something at their end to display the relevant info from the feed.

Can we chat about this?

Just need to understand the exact nature of things. I don't envisige a problem though

Jagdeep

________________________________

Hi Finn,

I'm guessing Visit Britain wouldn't want Business events, although I don't think you currently have any, it's more if they got added and started to get sent in future? Also I assume we'd only deliver upcoming events?

If Visit Britain are happy to accept the XML fields/format we use internally, then it's probably a couple of days work to create the web service to return the relevant events as XML and expose them via an API key.

Past experience has shown that even the simplest feeds tends to have a bit of bedding in the first time it is used, hence why I think we'd need a couple of days to get it working.

It would be best to be clear what we are delivering in advance and get that signed off as constant back / forth and changes with regards to fields etc. will quickly drive the cost up. The simplest format is for us to deliver the XML feed in our own format using our own field names. Although it may be that Visit Britain would prefer it as an extended RSS feed with each field as optional meta data values.

The question to them is probably "Are you OK pulling back a XML feed back of all upcoming events in 2012 internal format once a day via a web service and caching the results?"

re. picking it up once a day would be no issue at all, once an hour would be no issue, it's more if every request to Visit Britain's homepage caused a hit on 2012 that we may have issues. In fact a XML web service call would come direct from the CMS (which we host) and not from the live environment at all. The easiest thing would be for Visit Britain to just 'cache' a local copy each day and then render their local copy of the file/data.

Jamie

Hi Jagdeep,

Finn is talking to Visit Britain about supplying them with a 'feed' of events.

My concern was them retrieving a (RSS style) feed 'real time' and then displaying it prominently on their site ie. the home page. I have asked Finn to dissuade them from doing this and instead ask them retrieve the feed once a a day an cache a local copy on their servers.

If they retive a feed via a web service + API key it will actually come direct from the CMS / in which case the caching is almost a pre-requisite rather than an option.

As long as they cache a copy daily or hourly I envisage no problems.

Jamie

I know Finn started this off with you - but could you point me in the direction of the right ticket?  I think it may be something we would like to pursue - and quickly.  I was hoping to use the map (and the work Stamen had done) but their lack of response during my holiday has left it looking impossible to achieve for the listings go-live next week. (that said, could you look at this: http://data.map.london2012.com/points.php?format=atom&category=event&bbox=%2D23%2E6692%2C48%2E7894%2C15%2E0027%2C61%2E4261 and tell me how far off you think it is? I don't know how to check what information is actually in the feed - we'd want the date of the event, and event type, as well as title and short description)  Do you think it's something you could do quickly?  Ideal delivery date would be Friday!

Hi Liz,

See below and ticket..
http://postcms.zendesk.com/tickets/973

You may want to read a bit back on the ticket, the question was over what was meant by "An Events RSS" feed and did you mean a "real" structured events feed / web service or just the title/description of the five latest events that they can pull in (as an RSS feed)

thanks

Jamie

• Hi Finn,

I'm guessing Visit Britain wouldn't want Business events, although I don't think you currently have any, it's more if they got added and started to get sent in future? Also I assume we'd only deliver upcoming events?

If Visit Britain are happy to accept the XML fields/format we use internally, then it's probably a couple of days work to create the web service to return the relevant events as XML and expose them via an API key.

Past experience has shown that even the simplest feeds tends to have a bit of bedding in the first time it is used, hence why I think we'd need a couple of days to get it working.

It would be best to be clear what we are delivering in advance and get that signed off as constant back / forth and changes with regards to fields etc. will quickly drive the cost up. The simplest format is for us to deliver the XML feed in our own format using our own field names. Although it may be that Visit Britain would prefer it as an extended RSS feed with each field as optional meta data values.

The question to them is probably "Are you OK pulling back a XML feed back of all upcoming events in 2012 internal format once a day via a web service and caching the results?"

re. picking it up once a day would be no issue at all, once an hour would be no issue, it's more if every request to Visit Britain's homepage caused a hit on 2012 that we may have issues. In fact a XML web service call would come direct from the CMS (which we host) and not from the live environment at all. The easiest thing would be for Visit Britain to just 'cache' a local copy each day and then render their local copy of the file/data.

Jamie

I think somewhere in between? So the ideal content would be:

Name of event

Event dates

Event description

Venue name

Venue address, postcode or geo codes.

A unique id in case we need to update the event

website address

They want *everything* (rather than the most recent 5-20) but perhaps the best way to do that would actually be to give them a download (spreadsheet) of everything we have registered so far, and then start monitoring the feed from a certain point?

It would be easiest to just give them a web API to a XML document of al events ie. <events><event id="1">...</event><event id="2">...</event></events> with all events that they can poll each day (or whenever they want)

Excel spreadsheets are notoriously bad way of exchanging data electronically, I'm not sure the current export has an ID field either?

Just reread the rest of your paragraph.

1) I was hoping to use the map / Stamen

Yes that's almost exactly what I meant what I asked ' did you really mean an RSS feed or do you need a real XML feed' 

That's more an RSS / Atom feed that you would pull in on your RSS reader web site 

ie. it's doesn't have 

- an id for each event
- it's doesn't have all the fields ie. a dedicated start / end date etc. no event type etc.
- it's doesn't contain all events 
- finally it uses blocks of CDATA to deliver the summary (which in an RSS reader won't be an issue). But Visit Britain may need a 'clean' XML feed without blocks of markup wrapped in CDATA. CDATA is a simple way of sending over a block of 'stuff' there is no structure / validity to what is in that block, this may or may not be an issue depending on what they are doing with the feed.

2) Do you think it's something you could do quickly?

Yes/No, any feed tends to take at least a day to write and another day to test, handover, bed in and answer questions on etc.

3) Ideal delivery date would be Friday!

Would be very tight, would need sign off today / to start on it tomorrow 

and may have to push back if we hit issues with Visit Britain ie. they have issues parsing it / need lots of hand holding.

Let us know if you want us to get started, we could deliver a 'light' webservice endpoint that just returned the ID's of all events with a last modified date and another endpoint that returned each event. This would enable Visit Britain to only have to pull the actual event data once.

ie.

get-all-events (returns an id for each event and a last modified date as XML)
get-event (returns a single event as XML)

Jamie
Like that idea – how tricky is the API to XML doc to create?

I think probably a day to code the API endpoints but probably another day to bed in test / handover / tweak.

Event the simplest feed often turns out to be never quite as simple as it first seems.

Shall we get started?

So to recap what we're suggesting;

i) /api/get-all-events - An API/endpoint/web service which returns an XML document of all events and a last modified (or creation) date for all *published* events.

Which returns something like this, 

<events>
	<event id="345" path="events/walking-as-one.php" modification-date="201006151554" name="Walking As One" />
	<event id="346" path="events/event2.php" modification-date="201006151554" name="Event 2" />
	<event id="347" path="events/event3.phpp" modification-date="201006151554" name="Event 3" />
</events>

ii) get-event/#URL# - An API/endpoint/web service which returns a single event

<page id="2914250" display-name="Walking As One" modification-date="201006151554">
	<eventType type="select">Photography & Visual arts</eventType>
 <startDate type="date">20100724</startDate>
 <timings type="text">6.00pm</timings>
 <body type="text">Some body text</body>
	... any other fields or meta data on the event ...
</page>

* We could combine the above the rational for not doing this is that is so that only new or modified events need to be retrieved in full.

Both of these will use/need an unique API key (supplied) to access the API

Neither API should be be polled real time ie. the API should be polled once a day (or hourly if really required) and cached in a local DB or filesystem.

Jamie
Hold off – I think they’re going to be happy just receiving a copy of the CSV export instead...
